title: New SAF tax credit included in proposed California budget | Biofuels International Magazine
description:
California’s newly proposed 2026–27 state budget put forward by Governor Gavin Newsom includes a significant climate and clean-fuel initiative: the introduction of a tax credit to promote sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production within the state.
The measure would create a tax credit against diesel excise tax liability specifically to encourage in-state production of SAF, which is a lower-carbon alternative to traditional jet fuel and plays an important role in reducing greenhouse gas emissions in the aviation sector, one of the most challenging areas to decarbonise.
This SAF tax credit is part of a broader suite of budgetary proposals designed to steer California’s economy towards more sustainable industries, although it must still be approved by the state legislature during the budget process.
If adopted, it would mark a notable step by a US state in using fiscal policy to directly support the growth of alternative fuels.
This approach mirrors federal efforts to encourage SAF through tax incentives, though California’s version is notably targeted at in-state production.
text:
California’s newly proposed 2026–27 state budget put forward by Governor Gavin Newsom includes a significant climate and clean-fuel initiative: the introduction of a tax credit to promote sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production within the state.

The measure would create a tax credit against diesel excise tax liability specifically to encourage in-state production of SAF, which is a lower-carbon alternative to traditional jet fuel and plays an important role in reducing greenhouse gas emissions in the aviation sector, one of the most challenging areas to decarbonise.

The rationale behind this proposal is to support California’s ambitious climate and air-quality goals by incentivising private investment and scaling up clean transportation fuel technologies.

By reducing the tax burden for SAF producers, the state aims to make sustainable aviation fuels more competitive with conventional petroleum-based jet fuels, helping to accelerate market adoption and stimulate innovation in a sector that currently accounts for a large portion of transport-related emissions.

This SAF tax credit is part of a broader suite of budgetary proposals designed to steer California’s economy towards more sustainable industries, although it must still be approved by the state legislature during the budget process.

If adopted, it would mark a notable step by a US state in using fiscal policy to directly support the growth of alternative fuels. This approach mirrors federal efforts to encourage SAF through tax incentives, though California’s version is notably targeted at in-state production.

title: EU Hydrogen Matchmaking Platform Opens for Buyer Expressions of Interest | Rigzone
description:
The European Commission on Tuesday made the first call for buyer expressions of interest for hydrogen supply offers under a matchmaking platform launched last year.
European Energy and Housing Commissioner Dan Jørgensen said, "The EU's Hydrogen Mechanism is a new, innovative tool to help develop the market.
The Hydrogen Mechanism will operate until 2029 under the European Hydrogen Bank, as specified under the EU's "Regulation on the Internal Markets for Renewable Gas, Natural Gas and Hydrogen”.
The Hydrogen Bank is an EU Innovation Fund financing platform to scale up the renewable hydrogen value chain.
"It does not directly provide financing or support negotiations which may take place, outside of the platform, between participants following their connections through the platform", the platform says.
text:
The European Commission on Tuesday made the first call for buyer expressions of interest for hydrogen supply offers under a matchmaking platform launched last year.

In a call to suppliers that closed earlier this month, European and international companies placed offers from over 260 projects, the Commission's Directorate-General for Energy said in an online statement. Buyers now have until March 20, 2026 to indicate interest in the offers, according to the statement.

"As part of the EU Energy and Raw Materials Platform, the Hydrogen Mechanism connects potential off-takers in Europe with suppliers of renewable and low-carbon hydrogen or derivatives, including ammonia, methanol, eMethane and electro-sustainable aviation fuel", the Directorate-General said.

"Hydrogen plays an important role in decarbonizing industrial processes and industries for which reducing carbon emissions is both urgent and hard to achieve", it added. "At the same time, it can strengthen the competitiveness of Europe’s industry and leverage the EU market towards more security of supply, diversification and decarbonization".

European Energy and Housing Commissioner Dan Jørgensen said, "The EU's Hydrogen Mechanism is a new, innovative tool to help develop the market. With strong interest shown from suppliers across Europe and beyond, the initiative is off to a very promising start".

The broader European Union Energy and Raw Materials Platform lets buyers in the 27-member bloc offer demand for biomethane, hydrogen, natural gas and raw materials. The online platform seeks to give EU companies cost-effective and efficient access to such commodities by enabling negotiations with competing suppliers, according to the Commission.

The Hydrogen Mechanism will operate until 2029 under the European Hydrogen Bank, as specified under the EU's "Regulation on the Internal Markets for Renewable Gas, Natural Gas and Hydrogen”. The Hydrogen Bank is an EU Innovation Fund financing platform to scale up the renewable hydrogen value chain.

The platform's user guide says, "The EU Energy and Raw Materials Platform enables the collection and exchange of market data, information about demand and supply, demand aggregation and joint purchasing of energy-related products and raw materials".

"It does not directly provide financing or support negotiations which may take place, outside of the platform, between participants following their connections through the platform", the platform says.

The Gas Mechanism is expected to replace AggregateEU, a mechanism in which gas suppliers compete to book demand placed by companies in the EU and its Energy Community partner countries. AggregateEU has been extended, having initially been meant only for the 2023-24 winter.

In March 2025 the Directorate-General said a second midterm round for AggregateEU matched nearly 20 billion cubic meters (706.29 billion cubic feet). Midterm rounds offered six-month contracts for potential suppliers during a buyer-seller partnership of up to five years.

Announcing the first midterm tender February 1, 2024, the Directorate-General said, "In early 2024, with the effects of the energy crisis still not over, AggregateEU is introducing a different concept of mid-term tenders in order to address the growing demand for stability and predictability from buyers and sellers of natural gas".

"Under such tenders, buyers will be able to submit their demand for seasonal six-month periods (for a minimum 1,800,000 MWh for LNG and 30,000 for NBP per period), going from April 2024 to October 2029", the Directorate-General said then. "This is intended to support sellers in identifying buyers who might be interested in a longer trading partnership - i.e. up to five years".

NBP gas, or National Balancing Point gas, refers to gas from the national transmission systems of EU states.

A total of seven rounds were conducted under AggregateEU, pooling over 119 Bcm of demand and attracting 191 Bcm of offers. Nearly 100 Bcm have been matched, according to the latest results announcement March 26, 2025.

To contact the author, email jov.onsat@rigzone.com

title: Farm, fuel leaders push for solutions to close Iowa's corn 'demand gap' | The Gazette
authors: Olivia Cohen, K.J. Pilcher, Elijah Decious, Shauneen Miranda
description:
Agriculture economists said year-round production of E15 — a gasoline blend that is 15 percent ethanol — would help boost demand for Iowa corn.
Advocates said moving to a fuel blend with a higher concentration of ethanol would close Iowa’s demand gap by 2031.
However, Dave Miller, senior economist with Decision Innovation Solutions, said this wouldn’t be a permanent solution to the state’s corn demand issues.
A need for permanent solutions Mark Mueller, president of the Iowa Corn Growers Association, farms corn and soybeans in near Waverly.
The study pointed to the ultra-low carbon ethanol market, which involves lowering the carbon intensity of ethanol through carbon capture sequestration.
text:
A new report points to the growing gap between the amount of corn Iowa grows and demand for the crop, and suggests new pathways that could keep demand — and prices — up.

The study, prepared for the Iowa Renewable Fuels Association and Iowa Corn Growers Association by Urbandale-based economic research and analysis firm Decision Innovation Solutions, reports that Iowa corn producers continue to lead the U.S. in corn production.

However, if demand isn’t buoyed through increased ethanol use or through the ultra-low carbon ethanol market, the study warns that a $2.50 drop per bushel of corn could “erase $6.9 billion in gross income from corn farmers in Iowa using 2025 production.” At this rate, the report states, by 2050, farmers could lose $9 billion in gross income per year.

Monte Shaw, executive director of the Iowa Renewable Fuels Association, said Iowa farmers and the state’s agriculture market are currently in a crisis that mirrors the farm crisis of the 1980s.

“I'd say it's a ‘small c’ crisis, but I think if we don't do anything in the next couple of years, or sooner, it's going to be a ‘capital c’ crisis,” he said.

Agriculture economists said year-round production of E15 — a gasoline blend that is 15 percent ethanol — would help boost demand for Iowa corn.

More than half the corn produced in Iowa — and about 40 percent nationwide — is used to produce ethanol. Currently, the dominant form of vehicle gasoline in Iowa is E10, made up of 10 percent ethanol.

Advocates said moving to a fuel blend with a higher concentration of ethanol would close Iowa’s demand gap by 2031.

However, Dave Miller, senior economist with Decision Innovation Solutions, said this wouldn’t be a permanent solution to the state’s corn demand issues.

“E15 is not a sufficient long-term solution,” Miller said. “It is a near-term solution that is very powerful.”

Miller said corn makes up about 29 percent of Iowa’s overall agriculture cash receipts, making it the biggest driver of the state’s agriculture economy, while 24 percent is from hogs, 18 percent is from soybeans, and 17 percent is from cattle. About 12 percent of the state’s total ag cash receipts of $37.6 billion comes from “other” production.

A need for permanent solutions

Mark Mueller, president of the Iowa Corn Growers Association, farms corn and soybeans in near Waverly. He said he’s concerned about Iowa’s current corn market.

“I am a fourth-generation farmer, and I am nervous that there won't be a fifth generation Mueller farming on my family land,” he said in virtual press conference Wednesday that shared Decision Innovation Solutions’ findings. “We need more places to move our corn, and while Iowa Corn is working toward that, it's just a tough, tough road for the farming community.”

To find a more permanent solution and create better balance between supply and demand of Iowa corn, the economic research company identified new pathways that could absorb Iowa farmers’ surplus corn and make demand sustainable.

The study pointed to the ultra-low carbon ethanol market, which involves lowering the carbon intensity of ethanol through carbon capture sequestration.

Shaw said work like that already is underway in Nebraska, which is home to the Tallgrass Trailblazer CO2 pipeline. The pipeline started moving emissions from nearly a dozen Nebraska ethanol plants and one in Iowa in November 2025.

A similar pipeline has been proposed by Iowa-based Summit Carbon Solutions. The 2,500-mile pipeline would pass through five states, including Iowa, to capture CO2 from ethanol plants and bury it in North Dakota.

The Iowa study also pointed to new industrial markets as another path forward for corn growers. Miller said big markets, like marine fuels, are pivoting from fossil fuels and looking toward ethanol and methanol fuels.

Miller likened it to the sustainable aviation fuel market, which he said is a 35 billion gallon a year market.

“Our projections would suggest that ethanol could take maybe about 20 percent of that market. It's a solution for the future in Iowa,” Miller said. “The biggest demand changer we've had in Iowa in the last 20 years has been ethanol. The growth of the ethanol industry has really transformed Iowa.”

Shaw said Iowa’s agriculture market is at a tipping point as producers are “desperately” in need of new pathways for demand.

“If not, I think we have some very bleak days ahead of us,” Shaw said. “We don't want the current farm income price crisis to go from a ‘small c’ to a ‘capital c.’”

Olivia Cohen covers energy and environment for The Gazette and is a corps member with Report for America, a national service program that places journalists in local newsrooms to report on under-covered issues. She is also a contributing writer for the Ag and Water Desk, an independent journalism collaborative focusing on the Mississippi River Basin.

Sign up for our curated, weekly environment & outdoors newsletter.

Comments: olivia.cohen@thegazette.com

title: Europe Business Jet Market Size, Share & Growth, 2034
authors: Market Data Forecast, Market Data Forecast ltd
description:
Europe Business Jet Market Size The size of the Europe business jet market was worth USD 5.82 billion in 2025.
COUNTRY-LEVEL ANALYSIS United Kingdom Business Jet Market Analysis The United Kingdom led the business jet market in Europe in 2025 by holding 23.8% of the regional market share.
Germany Business Jet Market Analysis Germany commanded a notable share of the European business jet market in 2025 with activity rooted in its industrial export economy and engineering precision culture.
Switzerland Business Jet Market Analysis Switzerland is anticipated to hold a noteworthy share of the European business jet market over the forecast period.
Italy Business Jet Market Analysis Italy is predicted to showcase a healthy CAGR in the European business jet market during the forecast period, with dynamics shaped by fashion, luxury, and regional economic disparity.
text:
Europe Business Jet Market Size

The size of the Europe business jet market was worth USD 5.82 billion in 2025. The regional market is anticipated to grow at a CAGR of 2.52% from 2026 to 2034 and be worth USD 7.28 billion by 2034 from USD 5.97 billion in 2026.

Business jets are private turbine powered aircrafts configured for executive transport across the civilian and corporate sectors. These aircraft serve as critical mobility tools for multinational enterprises, high-net-worth individuals, and specialized missions such as medical evacuation or government transport. Unlike commercial aviation, business aviation in Europe operates primarily through a fragmented network of hundreds of general aviation airports, many of which lack customs or night curfew restrictions, enabling point-to-point efficiency unattainable via scheduled carriers. According to Eurocontrol, business jet flights numbered in the hundreds of thousands in European airspace in 2024, reflecting sustained reliance on private aviation for time-sensitive missions. As per the European Union Aviation Safety Agency, a significant share of Europe’s business jet fleet is registered in offshore jurisdictions such as the Isle of Man, Malta, and Aruba due to favorable tax and regulatory frameworks. Furthermore, the European Commission’s Single European Sky ATM Research program notes that business aviation accounts for approximately 8% of total civil air traffic movements, yet contributes disproportionately to airspace flexibility and regional connectivity, particularly in remote or underserved areas where scheduled service is economically unviable.

MARKET DRIVERS

Rising Demand for Time-Efficient Executive Mobility in Multinational Corporate Operations

European businesses increasingly rely on business jets to maintain operational agility across fragmented regulatory and geographic landscapes, which is one of the key factors driving the growth of the European business jet market. As per the European Business Aviation Association, a majority of Fortune 500 companies with European headquarters utilize private aviation to coordinate cross-border management visits, factory audits, and client engagements. The average commercial flight itinerary between secondary European cities, such as Stuttgart to Toulouse or Gothenburg to Valencia, often involves at least one connection and a total travel time exceeding several hours. In contrast, a light jet completes the same route in under two hours door to door. Studies on executive productivity confirm that business jet users save significant time compared to commercial alternatives, which translates into thousands of additional productive hours annually for large corporate subsidiaries. This time advantage is especially critical in sectors like pharmaceuticals, automotive, and finance, where rapid decision-making and site visits directly impact revenue. As supply chains decentralize and talent pools scatter across rural innovation hubs, the need for flexible point-to-point access intensifies, making business jets not a luxury but a strategic operational asset.

Growth of Ultra High Net Worth Population Driving Fractional and Full Ownership

Europe’s expanding cohort of ultra-high-net-worth individuals is fuelling sustained demand for private aviation through direct ownership and fractional programs, which is another major factor contributing to the growth of the European business jet market. According to the Global Wealth Report published by Credit Suisse, the number of individuals in Europe with investable assets exceeding 30 million US dollars grew in 2024. These individuals prioritize privacy, security, and schedule control, as these are the attributes inherently delivered by business jets. Unlike commercial first class, private aviation eliminates exposure to crowded terminals, security lines, and fixed departure times. Surveys by UBS Wealth Management found that many European UHNWIs view private jet access as essential for personal and family mobility, particularly for leisure travel to destinations such as Sardinia, the Alps, or the Greek islands, where commercial service is seasonal or non-existent. Additionally, the rise of family office structures has institutionalized aviation as a managed asset with dedicated flight departments overseeing safety, maintenance, and compliance. This demographic tailwind ensures baseline demand even during economic slowdowns, as wealth preservation and lifestyle continuity remain non-negotiable.

MARKET RESTRAINTS

Stringent Environmental Regulations and Carbon Pricing Increase Operational Costs

The Europe business jet market faces mounting pressure from climate policies that directly elevate flight expenses and constrain operations. According to the European Commission, all business jet operators flying within the EU must participate in the EU Emissions Trading System, which in 2024 priced carbon allowances at over 85 euros per ton. For a typical light jet emitting nearly two tons of CO₂ per hour, this adds significant compliance costs to every flight hour. Furthermore, the EU’s ReFuelEU Aviation mandate requires that 2% of all aviation fuel supplied at EU airports be sustainable aviation fuel by 2025, rising to 70% by 2050. As per the European Environment Agency, sustainable aviation fuel currently costs several times more than conventional Jet A1, making compliance financially burdensome for small operators. Several countries have introduced additional levies; France imposes a departure tax on private jets, while the Netherlands plans a progressive noise and emissions surcharge by 2026. These cumulative costs disproportionately impact light and mid-size jet operators who lack the economies of scale to absorb them, potentially forcing fleet reductions or market exits.

Public and Political Backlash Against the Perceived Inequity of Private Aviation

Business aviation in Europe increasingly contends with social stigma and policy hostility rooted in perceptions of excess amid economic and climate crises, which is further hindering the growth of the European business jet market. According to a 2024 Eurobarometer survey, a majority of EU citizens believe private jets should be banned or heavily taxed due to their disproportionate carbon footprint relative to passenger capacity. This sentiment has translated into concrete political action; the European Parliament’s Transport Committee proposed a continent-wide ban on short-haul business jet flights where rail alternatives under six hours exist, which is a measure that would affect a large share of current operations between major European cities. Local governments have also restricted access; London City Airport prohibits private jet arrivals during peak hours, while Geneva and Nice impose steep night landing fees. Media scrutiny intensifies the pressure as investigations have linked offshore aircraft registrations to tax avoidance schemes, prompting calls for transparency reforms. This reputational and regulatory headwind complicates fleet planning, market expansion, and brand positioning for operators and manufacturers alike.

MARKET OPPORTUNITIES

Adoption of Sustainable Aviation Fuel and Electrification Pathways Creates Green Premium Segment

The emergence of low-carbon propulsion technologies is opening a new value tier for environmentally conscious operators, which is a prominent opportunity in the European business jet market. According to the European Business Aviation Association, dozens of business jet operators in Europe now offer carbon-neutral flight options through sustainable aviation fuel blending or verified offset programs. Leading manufacturers such as Dassault and Gulfstream have certified their latest models for 100% sustainable aviation fuel use, which is enabling immediate emissions reduction without airframe modification. In 2024, the European Commission approved significant funding under the Innovation Fund to support sustainable aviation fuel production plants in Spain and the Netherlands, with output prioritized for business aviation due to its early adopter profile. As per a survey by VistaJet, a majority of corporate clients are willing to pay a premium for flights powered by certified sustainable fuel. This green premium segment not only mitigates reputational risk but also aligns with corporate net-zero commitments under the EU Taxonomy, creating a strategic differentiation avenue in an otherwise mature market.

Expansion of On-Demand Jet Card and Subscription Models Lowers Entry Barriers

The proliferation of flexible access models is democratizing business aviation beyond traditional ownership circles, which is offering prominent opportunities in the European business jet market. According to the European Business Aviation Association, fractional and jet card programs now account for a growing share of private flight hours in Europe compared to earlier years. Companies such as LunaJets and Victor offer subscription plans starting at accessible annual fees, granting guaranteed availability without capital outlay or management overhead. These models appeal to mid-sized enterprises and affluent professionals who fly 25 to 50 hours per year, which is below the threshold for cost-effective ownership. According to a PwC analysis, jet card users achieve lower total cost per flight hour compared to ad hoc charter due to volume pricing and fixed hourly rates. Additionally, digital platforms provide real-time pricing, fleet availability, and carbon footprint tracking, enhancing transparency and ease of use. As digital payment infrastructure and dynamic pricing algorithms mature, this on-demand ecosystem is transforming business aviation from an asset-intensive luxury into a scalable mobility service accessible to a broader economic stratum.

MARKET CHALLENGES

Fragmented Air Traffic Management and Airport Access Restrictions Limit Operational Flexibility

Despite the Single European Sky initiative, business jet operators continue to face inefficiencies due to national airspace fragmentation and localized airport constraints, which are major challenges to the growth of the European business jet market. According to Eurocontrol, average en route flight times for business jets in Europe remain longer than optimal due to uncoordinated air traffic flows and restricted military zones. Furthermore, hundreds of general aviation airports across the EU impose noise quotas, night curfews, or slot limitations that restrict access during critical business hours. According to a study by the European Business Aviation Association, many operators experienced denied airport access in the past year due to ad hoc restrictions in countries such as Germany, France, and Switzerland. These bottlenecks undermine the core value proposition of private aviation and force rerouting that increases fuel burn and carbon output. Until the EU fully implements centralized flow management and harmonizes noise certification standards across member states, business jets will operate in a patchwork regulatory environment that erodes efficiency and reliability.

Supply Chain Constraints for Advanced Avionics and Engine Components Delay Fleet Renewal

The Europe business jet market contends with persistent delivery bottlenecks driven by global shortages of high-specification aerospace components. According to the European Union Aviation Safety Agency, lead times for next-generation flight deck systems have extended significantly due to semiconductor allocation priorities favoring commercial airliners. Similarly, engine manufacturers report backlogs exceeding two years for popular light and mid-size jet engines. As per a 2024 audit by Roland Berger, European operators planning fleet upgrades faced delays in aircraft delivery compared to pre-pandemic norms. This supply constraint forces businesses to retain older, less efficient aircraft longer, increasing maintenance costs and carbon intensity. Without dedicated allocation channels or regionalized component manufacturing, the market will remain vulnerable to aerospace industry-wide capacity limits that suppress modernization and sustainability goals.

REPORT COVERAGE

SEGMENTAL ANALYSIS

By Body Type Insights

The mid-size jet segment accounted for the major share of 40.8% of the regional market in 2025. The dominating position of the mid-size jet segment in the European market is driven by its optimal balance of range, performance, and operating economics for intra-European and transatlantic missions. Mid-size jets such as the Cessna Citation Latitude, Bombardier Challenger 350, and Embraer Praetor 500 offer 2,500 to 3,500 nautical mile range and stand-up cabins that suit the most common European business itineraries. As per Eurocontrol, a majority of business jet flights in Europe originate or terminate within the EU’s core economic triangle of London, Frankfurt, and Milan. These routes typically require 1,000 to 2,000 nautical miles of range while also supporting transatlantic legs when needed. Independent analyses confirm that mid-size jets achieve the lowest cost per seat mile among all categories for missions under 3,000 nautical miles due to fuel efficiency and lower maintenance intensity than large jets. Their eight to nine-passenger capacity also aligns with typical executive team sizes, avoiding the underutilization common with larger cabins.

The light/very-light jet segment is the fastest-growing segment in the European market and is estimated to register a CAGR of 7.07% over the forecast period. The rise of subscription-based mobility is driving demand for efficient small cabin aircraft. As per the European Business Aviation Association, a significant share of private flight hours in 2024 were conducted through jet card or membership programs, with light jets such as the Phenom 300 and Citation CJ4 forming the backbone of these fleets due to low hourly operating costs. Companies like LunaJets and Victor report that many new clients in Germany and the Netherlands opted for light jet access plans priced between 15,000 and 40,000 euros annually. A PwC study found that these models reduce entry barriers compared to fractional ownership, enabling mid-sized enterprises and affluent professionals to adopt private aviation for the first time. This democratization creates a structural growth vector beyond traditional ultra-high-net-worth ownership.

By End User Insights

The businesses and corporate entities segment captured the leading share of the European business jet market in 2025 due to the strategic integration of private aviation into multinational operational frameworks. European corporations use business jets to maintain agility across fragmented regulatory and logistical landscapes. For instance, companies with pan-European manufacturing footprints conduct numerous executive flights annually to coordinate audits, supplier negotiations, and crisis response. Commercial alternatives often lack direct routes to secondary industrial hubs such as Toulouse, Wolfsburg, or Lund, forcing multi-leg itineraries that waste significant time. A corporate jet reduces this to under four hours, enabling same-day round trips. As per the European Commission’s Single Market Observatory, a majority of Fortune 500 European subsidiaries consider private aviation essential for maintaining just-in-time supply chain oversight. This operational ROI justifies fleet investment even during economic uncertainty.

The charter/air-taxi operators segment is on the rise and is expected to record a CAGR of 8.05% over the forecast period. Technology-driven charter platforms have dramatically lowered access barriers through transparent real-time pricing and instant availability. As per the European Business Aviation Association, digital brokers such as Victor, LunaJets, and JetApp accounted for a growing share of ad hoc charter bookings in 2024 compared to earlier years. These platforms aggregate empty legs, utilize AI for route optimization, and offer fixed hourly rates, eliminating traditional opaque quoting. A Roland Berger analysis confirmed that digital charter users achieve lower costs per flight hour than traditional brokers due to reduced positioning and idle time. The rise of API integration with corporate travel management systems further embeds on-demand aviation into enterprise workflows, making it a seamless alternative to scheduled service for unpredictable trips.

By Ownership Model Insights

The pre-owned purchase segment occupied 36.4% of the regional market share in 2025 due to the value optimization in a capital-intensive and volatile asset class. Pre-owned jets offer 30 to 50% lower acquisition costs than new equivalents while delivering near-identical performance due to rigorous maintenance standards. As per the European Union Aviation Safety Agency, all aircraft registered in Europe must comply with mandatory airworthiness directives and undergo annual inspections regardless of age. For instance, mid-life aircraft often include factory-installed upgrades such as enhanced vision systems or updated interiors, reducing retrofit expenses. For corporations and high-net-worth individuals seeking asset efficiency, this residual value curve makes pre-owned the rational choice, particularly amid economic uncertainty.

The fractional ownership segment is anticipated to register a CAGR of 8.2% over the forecast period in the European business jet market. Fractional programs are increasingly adopted by companies that fly 50 to 200 hours annually, which is too much for charter but too little for full ownership. As per NetJets Europe, a majority of new fractional clients in 2024 were mid-sized European enterprises in sectors such as renewable energy, medtech, and fintech. These firms gain guaranteed availability, access to large cabin aircraft, and full operational support without managing crew, maintenance, or insurance. A PwC analysis found that fractional users achieve lower total cost per flight hour than full owners at this utilization level due to shared fixed expenses. As corporate sustainability reporting intensifies, fractional providers also offer carbon-neutral flight options, enhancing ESG alignment.

COUNTRY-LEVEL ANALYSIS

United Kingdom Business Jet Market Analysis

The United Kingdom led the business jet market in Europe in 2025 by holding 23.8% of the regional market share. The dominance of the UK in the European market is driven by its global financial hub status, extensive general aviation infrastructure, and favorable tax environment for aircraft registration. As per the UK Civil Aviation Authority, hundreds of business jets are registered in the UK, with London Oxford, Biggin Hill, and Farnborough forming a high-density corridor that handles a significant portion of European private jet movements. The country’s time zone advantage enables same-day flights to both Asia and the Americas, making it a strategic base for multinational corporations. Additionally, the UK’s departure from the EU has not diminished its appeal; the Civil Aviation Authority maintains EASA-aligned safety standards while offering streamlined customs for non-EU flights. This combination of connectivity, regulatory clarity, and service depth ensures the UK remains a central hub of European business aviation.

France Business Jet Market Analysis

France captured the second leading share of the European market in 2025 with demand fuelled by luxury conglomerates, aerospace leadership, and strategic Mediterranean access. According to France’s Directorate General for Civil Aviation, hundreds of business jets are registered in the country, with Paris Le Bourget serving as Europe’s busiest business airport. French luxury groups such as LVMH, Kering, and L’Oréal operate dedicated fleets for global executive coordination, while Dassault Aviation’s Falcon production in Bordeaux anchors local industry expertise. France also leads in environmental regulation; its private jet departure tax and proposed short-haul restrictions reflect a dual identity as both an aviation hub and climate policy pioneer. This tension drives demand for sustainable aviation fuel and newer efficient models as operators seek to balance operational needs with social license.

Germany Business Jet Market Analysis

Germany commanded a notable share of the European business jet market in 2025 with activity rooted in its industrial export economy and engineering precision culture. As per the German Federal Aviation Office, hundreds of business jets serve the country’s Mittelstand as mid-sized industrial champions that drive a large share of German exports. These companies rely on private aviation to maintain just-in-time oversight of global supply chains, particularly in the automotive and machinery sectors. Frankfurt Egelsbach and Munich Oberpfaffenhofen are key hubs with EASA Part 145 maintenance facilities, ensuring rapid turnaround. Unlike leisure-focused markets, German usage is overwhelmingly mission-critical, with most flights linked to factory audits or client visits. This utilitarian approach ensures steady demand, insulated from consumer sentiment shifts and aligned with Germany’s export-dependent economic model.

Switzerland Business Jet Market Analysis

Switzerland is anticipated to hold a noteworthy share of the European business jet market over the forecast period. Despite its small size, due to its role as a global wealth and diplomacy center. According to the Swiss Federal Office of Civil Aviation, hundreds of business jets are registered in the country, benefiting from political neutrality, low VAT on maintenance, and traditions that attract international UHNWIs. Airports such as Geneva and Lugano offer discreet 24-hour operations with customs pre-clearance for Schengen and non-Schengen flights. The country’s mountainous terrain and limited commercial service to alpine resorts further justify private access. According to UBS Wealth Management, many Swiss-based family offices include aviation in their asset portfolios. This convergence of wealth, privacy, and geography creates a high-value concentrated market that punches far above its population weight.

Italy Business Jet Market Analysis

Italy is predicted to showcase a healthy CAGR in the European business jet market during the forecast period, with dynamics shaped by fashion, luxury, and regional economic disparity. According to the Italian Civil Aviation Authority, hundreds of business jets are registered, primarily serving Milan-based fashion houses, automotive magnates, and industrial families in the North. Airports such as Milan Linate and Olbia cater to seasonal leisure traffic to Sardinia and the Amalfi Coast, driving summer peak demand. However, the South lacks comparable infrastructure, limiting national fleet growth. Studies confirm that Italian UHNWIs often prioritize cabin comfort and design over range, reflecting cultural emphasis on aesthetics. Additionally, the government’s tax credit for sustainable aviation fuel adoption has accelerated fleet modernization among top owners. This blend of lifestyle-driven usage and emerging green incentives positions Italy as a unique and resilient niche within the European landscape.

COMPETITIVE LANDSCAPE

Competition in the Europe business jet market is characterized by a high-stakes contest among established manufacturers to balance performance, sustainability and service excellence amid tightening environmental and social scrutiny. The market is dominated by a handful of global OEMs who compete not on price but on range efficiency, cabin innovation, and lifecycle support. Barriers to entry are formidable due to EASA certification complexity, high R and D costs, and entrenched customer relationships. Competition is intensifying around environmental credentials as EU policies mandate sustainable aviation fuel use and carbon pricing, making fuel efficiency and SAF compatibility critical differentiators. At the same time, digitalization is reshaping customer expectations with demand for seamless flight planning, real-time maintenance tracking, and carbon reporting. Unlike commoditized transport segments, success here depends on integrated value combining aircraft performance, ground support, and regulatory foresight to retain corporate and ultra-high net worth clients in an era of climate accountability and operational transparency.

KEY MARKET PLAYERS

The leading companies operating in the Europe business jet market include:

Bombardier Inc.

Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation (General Dynamics Corporation)

Dassault Aviation SA

Textron Inc.

Embraer S.A.

TOP PLAYERS IN THE MARKET

Dassault Aviation is a premier European manufacturer renowned for its Falcon business jet family, which serves corporate, government, and special mission operators across the continent. The company contributes globally by setting benchmarks in aerodynamic efficiency, cabin comfort, and long-range performance with aircraft like the Falcon 6X and 8X. In Europe, Dassault has strengthened its position by achieving 100% sustainable aviation fuel certification for its entire Falcon line, enabling immediate carbon reduction. It also expanded its customer support network with new service centers in Geneva and Lisbon, offering EASA-certified maintenance and digital aircraft health monitoring. These actions reinforce its reputation for engineering excellence and operational reliability in a market increasingly demanding environmental accountability and service proximity.

Bombardier is a leading force in the Europe business jet market through its Challenger and Global series, known for spacious cabins, transcontinental range, and smooth ride quality. The company plays a pivotal global role by pioneering advanced wing designs and cabin pressurization systems that enhance passenger well-being. In Europe, Bombardier has reinforced its market presence by launching the Global 5500 and Challenger 3500 with updated interiors, reduced emissions, and full compliance with EU noise and carbon regulations. It also deepened partnerships with European fractional operators like Flexjet to standardize fleet configurations and streamline pilot training. Additionally, the company introduced a digital flight planning portal integrated with EU customs and slot coordination system,s enhancing operational efficiency for European clients.

Embraer Executive Jets delivers high-performance mid-size and light business aircraft with strong adoption across Europe’s corporate and charter segments. The company contributes globally by offering best-in-class economics in the Praetor and Phenom families, combining range efficiency and cabin innovation. In Europe, Embraer has strengthened its position by establishing an EASA-certified training center in Madrid and expanding its line maintenance network to 12 countries. It also achieved full sustainable aviation fuel approval for the Praetor 500 and 600, enabling European operators to meet ReFuelEU mandates. Recent collaborations with digital charter platforms like Victor ensure its aircraft remain central to the on-demand mobility ecosystem, driving accessibility beyond traditional ownership models.

TOP STRATEGIES USED BY THE KEY MARKET PARTICIPANTS

Key players in the Europe business jet market prioritize full certification for sustainable aviation fuel to comply with ReFuelEU mandates and meet corporate net-zero commitments. They expand EASA-certified maintenance and training infrastructure across major European hubs to ensure rapid turnaround and regulatory compliance. Companies enhance cabin technologies, focusing on air quality pressurization and connectivity to differentiate the passenger experience. Strategic partnerships with fractional operators and digital charter platforms increase fleet utilization and market reach. Additionally, they invest in digital flight support tools integrated with EU customs slot coordination and carbon reporting systems to streamline cross-border operations and reduce administrative burden for European clients.

MARKET SEGMENTATION

This research report on the Europe business jet market has been segmented and sub-segmented into the following categories.

By Body Type

Large Jet

Mid-Size Jet

Light / Very-Light Jet

By End User

Charter / Air-Taxi Operators

Training and Academic Institutions

Government and Special-Mission Operators

By Ownership Model

New Aircraft Purchase

Pre-Owned Purchase

title: New Economic Analysis Shows Solutions to Maintain Iowa's Corn and Ethanol Industry
description:
To ensure long-term profitability, we must deploy the technology to unlock the potential of ultra-low carbon ethanol—specifically through carbon capture and sequestration (CCS) pipelines.
Without the immediate adoption of nationwide E15 to stabilize domestic demand, and the critical infrastructure of a CCS pipeline to unlock global low-carbon markets, Iowa’s economic engine will stall.
It’s time to authorize nationwide E15 and secure Iowa’s position as the global leader in corn and ethanol production.
The Iowa Corn Growers Association (ICGA) is a 7,500-member strong grassroots-driven organization, headquartered in Johnston, Iowa, serving members across the state, and lobbying on agricultural issues on behalf of its farmer members to create opportunities for long-term Iowa corn grower profitability.
–Sydney Garrett, Iowa Corn Growers Association
text:
JOHNSTON, Iowa — Without immediate passage of nationwide, year-round E15 and access to ultra-low carbon ethanol markets, such as sustainable aviation fuel and marine fuel, Iowa’s corn and ethanol industry will continue its downward decline, according to a new study released by Iowa Corn and the Iowa Renewable Fuels Association.

The study’s release comes at a time when farmers are faced with a 2 billion bushel plus carryout and rising input costs for farm operations such as fertilizer, seed, machinery, etc. The study shows that corn prices are estimated at $1.52 per bushel. Without access expanded and new markets, many farmers may be forced to downsize or close their doors all together.

To ensure long-term profitability, we must deploy the technology to unlock the potential of ultra-low carbon ethanol—specifically through carbon capture and sequestration (CCS) pipelines. This infrastructure is the ‘missing link’ that allows us to capture emissions at the source, drastically lowering the carbon intensity of our fuel and providing the verifiable data required to participate in high-value global markets. Four of the top five export markets for U.S. ethanol—the EU, the UK, Canada, and Colombia— already have low-carbon fuel policies to help them meet their decarbonization goals.

Without the immediate adoption of nationwide E15 to stabilize domestic demand, and the critical infrastructure of a CCS pipeline to unlock global low-carbon markets, Iowa’s economic engine will stall. When our farms struggle, our energy independence weakens, fuel prices rise for every family, and we hand the lead in the global green energy race to our competitors. We have the resources, technology and soil to power the world with ethanol. To let this opportunity slip away is a risk our Iowa cannot afford.

“Without new corn demand, Iowa could be faced with a 1980s farm crisis,” said Mueller.

It’s time to authorize nationwide E15 and secure Iowa’s position as the global leader in corn and ethanol production.

The Iowa Corn Growers Association (ICGA) is a 7,500-member strong grassroots-driven organization, headquartered in Johnston, Iowa, serving members across the state, and lobbying on agricultural issues on behalf of its farmer members to create opportunities for long-term Iowa corn grower profitability. For more information, visit iowacorn.org.

–Sydney Garrett, Iowa Corn Growers Association

title: Climate Mythbusters: 7 Common Claims About Travel Emissions - Skift
description:
At Skift’s Megatrends event in London, some of the travel industry’s most commonly repeated statements about emissions and climate change were put to the test.
Hundreds of results, but how can you really tell the difference between hotels’ green credentials?
2: Carbon Offsets Are Reducing Emissions A review found that only 16% of carbon credits available today deliver real emissions reductions.
5: Green Hotels Are More Expensive to Build There are a number of studies and reports that have analysed the cost of constructing a so-called green building.
It’s been found that green buildings cost approximately 2% more to construct upfront.
text:
At Skift’s Megatrends event in London, some of the travel industry’s most commonly repeated statements about emissions and climate change were put to the test.

Are these widely heard claims actually true, or are they myths that need busting?

1: Travelers Won’t Pay a Sustainability Premium. Full Stop.

While Skift research found sustainability ranks dead last in traveler priorities behind comfort and location, the real problem isn’t willingness to pay, it’s visibility and trust.

Some 42% of U.S. travelers now express interest in greener options, up from 32% in recent years.

China and India show even stronger signals that travelers would be willing to look at greener options if they were given the choice.

But there is growing research that shows that information around sustainability is either not offered or unclear: 30% of U.S. travelers report encountering zero sustainable messaging when booking.

Take any typical search for a hotel at an online travel agent or search platform. Hundreds of results, but how can you really tell the difference between hotels’ green credentials? Which ones are using renewable energy over fossil fuels?

The industry hasn’t made it easy to choose greener options, even for those who want to.

2: Carbon Offsets Are Reducing Emissions

A review found that only 16% of carbon credits available today deliver real emissions reductions.

The offset market has been plagued by non-additional credits, projects like “protecting” forests that were never really under threat, or claiming credit for coal plants that were already scheduled to close. The kind where consumers are offered a tick box to pay a couple of dollars to make their trip green.

Travel companies, especially airlines, are backing away from offering passengers the offset tickbox, and in Skift polling, travelers ranked offsets at the bottom of sustainable choices they’d consider making, signalling they don’t trust where the money is going.

However, in recent months, reports show that while demand in the bulk of the offset market has fallen flat, there is growing demand for higher quality credits.

For example, the restoration of native forests or what’s known as additional carbon credits, removing CO2 from the atmosphere through carbon capture.

3: SAF Will Scale Beyond Virtue Signaling

Aviation needs approximately 450 million tonnes of sustainable aviation fuel, plant based oils, annually to reach net zero by 2050, accounting for sector growth.

In 2025, the industry used just 1.9 million tonnes, 0.6% of total fuel consumption. Rather than ramping up, SAF production moved backward in 2025.

Shell cancelled its $1 billion Rotterdam project that would have produced 820,000 tonnes annually. U.S. capacity projections collapsed 61%, from 4.8 million tonnes to 1.9 million tonnes, as investors turned away.

Most SAF today comes from used cooking oil, and supply is very limited.

Travel accounts for an estimated 9% of global greenhouse gas emissions annually. While other sectors emit more in absolute terms, travel’s trajectory is growing twice as fast as other industries.

In the UK, where sectors like agriculture, road transport, and buildings are reducing emissions, aviation is projected to account for 25% of all national emissions by 2035.

As other sectors decarbonize and travel demand rises, particularly with growing middle classes worldwide, the industry faces increasing scrutiny in the future.

5: Green Hotels Are More Expensive to Build

There are a number of studies and reports that have analysed the cost of constructing a so-called green building.

Think solar panels, heat pumps, recycled bricks and steal, circular economy furniture, lamps, electric kitchens and laundries.

It’s been found that green buildings cost approximately 2% more to construct upfront. However, when lifecycle costs are considered, buildings can deliver 14-19% in operational savings.

For example, IHG’s Voco Zeal Hotel on England’s south coast runs on 100% renewable energy with solar panels built into walls.

There is another very similar Zeal Hotel nearby and with the same number of rooms, providing an opportunity for valuable data and comparisons. The annual energy cost there is about £300,000.

The solar one is £100,000, a huge cost saving and zero emissions.

Corporate lodging payment service HRS found that hotels with the lowest emissions, water use, and waste per room night are cutting costs faster than those with the highest environmental impact.

6: Sustainable Stays Mean Higher Rack Rates for Guests

Pricing algorithms, location, timing, and facilities have far more impact on room rates than sustainability features. The pricing at hotels that claim to be net-zero or low carbon pricing largely matches competitors in the same area.

At Radisson’s net-zero hotel in Manchester city center, rates for a two-night stay align with similar hotels in the area.

The company confirmed no special incentives or premium pricing for the property. This pattern holds across other markets where low-carbon hotels using renewable energy price competitively with others.

7: 2050 Net-Zero Pledges Are Just Expensive PR

Net-zero commitments aren’t optional PR, they’re increasingly legal requirements.

Travel is a global industry, and net-zero by 2050 is law in many countries where companies operate. In the EU, all new buildings must be zero-emission from 2030, and existing buildings must achieve a 16% reduction in energy use, with 75% of current buildings considered inefficient.

Similar laws exist in Australia, the UK and China. Even U.S. companies operating in Europe and other markets must comply.

Skift’s in-depth reporting on climate issues is made possible through the financial support of Intrepid Travel. This backing allows Skift to bring you high-quality journalism on one of the most important topics facing our planet today. Intrepid is not involved in any decisions made by Skift’s editorial team.

title: STB rules application for Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern merger is incomplete
description:
The planned merger between Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern hit a snag on Jan. 16 when the Surface Transportation Board issued a unanimous decision finding that the merger application is incomplete and does not contain certain information required by the STB’s regulations.
As a result of the incomplete application, the STB rejected the merger application without prejudice and will allow the applicants to refile a revised application remedying the deficiencies identified by the board.
The board also noted the application is missing certain required schedules and documents that are part of the merger agreement, along with other technical, minor issues.
Union Pacific Corp. and Norfolk Southern Corp. first announced an agreement to complete the planned merger in July 2025, with Union Pacific agreeing to acquire Norfolk Southern in a stock and cash transaction.
The Union Pacific an Norfolk Southern in December 2025 formally filed an application with the STB requesting to combine the two railroads.
text:
The planned merger between Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern hit a snag on Jan. 16 when the Surface Transportation Board issued a unanimous decision finding that the merger application is incomplete and does not contain certain information required by the STB’s regulations.

As a result of the incomplete application, the STB rejected the merger application without prejudice and will allow the applicants to refile a revised application remedying the deficiencies identified by the board. The STB stressed that the Jan. 16 decision is based solely on the incompleteness of the application and should not be read as an indication of how the board might ultimately access any future revised application.

Specifically, the STB said the merger application does not contain future market share projections showing the combined effects of merger-related growth, diversions, and merger-influenced and other changes to market conditions that applicants anticipate. “These market-share projections are necessary because ‘[a]ny railroad combination,’ including an end-to-end combination, ‘entails a risk that the merged carrier would acquire and exploit increased market power.’ 49 C.F.R. § 1180.1(c)(2)(i),” the STB said in its statement.

The board also noted the application is missing certain required schedules and documents that are part of the merger agreement, along with other technical, minor issues. In addition, the STB said the related application for acquisition of control of the Terminal Railroad Association of St. Louis is a significant transaction, not a minor transaction as submitted to the board.

Union Pacific Corp. and Norfolk Southern Corp. first announced an agreement to complete the planned merger in July 2025, with Union Pacific agreeing to acquire Norfolk Southern in a stock and cash transaction. If agreement is finalized, the combined company would include more than 50,000 route miles spanning 43 states from the East Coast to the West Coast and linking approximately 100 ports.

The Union Pacific an Norfolk Southern in December 2025 formally filed an application with the STB requesting to combine the two railroads.

title: Airco Process to supply gas treatment systems for Finland's largest planned biogas plant
description:
Airco Process Technology has been chosen by bioconstruct GmbH to provide the full gas treatment system for what is set to become Finland’s largest biogas facility, in a development seen as a significant boost for the country’s renewable energy sector, reports Bioenergy Insight.
Working as a main subcontractor to bioconstruct, Airco Process will supply a complete, ready-to-operate solution.
This includes a biogas upgrading unit, two BioLNG production units, and a system to clean and liquefy carbon dioxide.
Daily output from the plant is projected at around 36 tonnes of bioLNG and about 77 tonnes of biogenic carbon dioxide.
Airco Process said it was pleased to be given a key role in the project, stating that the agreement shows trust in the company’s technology and engineering capabilities.
text:
Airco Process Technology has been chosen by bioconstruct GmbH to provide the full gas treatment system for what is set to become Finland’s largest biogas facility, in a development seen as a significant boost for the country’s renewable energy sector, reports Bioenergy Insight.

Working as a main subcontractor to bioconstruct, Airco Process will supply a complete, ready-to-operate solution. This includes a biogas upgrading unit, two BioLNG production units, and a system to clean and liquefy carbon dioxide. Together, these installations will allow biogas and its by-products to be processed and used efficiently.

The new plant is being developed by Nivalan Biokaasu Oy in partnership with Copenhagen Infrastructure Partners and is widely viewed as a landmark project for Finland’s bioenergy industry. Once in operation, the facility is expected to handle about 600,000 tonnes of raw materials each year.

Daily output from the plant is projected at around 36 tonnes of bioLNG and about 77 tonnes of biogenic carbon dioxide. Both outputs will be treated and liquefied at the site, making them suitable for use in industry, transport and other applications.

Airco Process said it was pleased to be given a key role in the project, stating that the agreement shows trust in the company’s technology and engineering capabilities.

The company added that the project marks an important step in strengthening renewable energy development in the region and supports the broader move towards cleaner and more sustainable energy supplies.

title: Perpetual Next USA to develop 3 biomethanol facilities in Southeastern US
description:
Perpetual Next USA will develop an additional of three biomass-to-biomethanol production facilities in the Southeastern U.S. Each of the facilities is designed to process approximately 1 million tons of sustainably sourced biomass feedstock per year.
This trend presents a considerable challenge regarding the pace at which the industry must scale new production facilities to meet future demand.
Biomethanol blueprint Perpetual Next anticipated the rapidly growing global demand for biomethanol and is currently rolling out its proprietary Biomethanol Blueprint across multiple production sites in Europe and the United States.
The blueprint integrates torrefaction, gasification, and methanol synthesis technologies and is designed to enable rapid, serial scale-up to commercial scale biomethanol production for the global market.
“Biomethanol is a key building block in the transition to low-carbon fuels for shipping, chemicals and industry,” said Rene Buwalda, CEO at Perpetual Next.
text:
Perpetual Next USA will develop an additional of three biomass-to-biomethanol production facilities in the Southeastern U.S. Each of the facilities is designed to process approximately 1 million tons of sustainably sourced biomass feedstock per year. Development of the sites will commence in 2026.

With the introduction of new governmental policies, such as Europe’s FuelEU program, and voluntary industry initiatives aimed at reducing carbon emissions, global demand for biomethanol is anticipated to grow substantially by 2050. This trend presents a considerable challenge regarding the pace at which the industry must scale new production facilities to meet future demand.

Biomethanol blueprint

Perpetual Next anticipated the rapidly growing global demand for biomethanol and is currently rolling out its proprietary Biomethanol Blueprint across multiple production sites in Europe and the United States. The blueprint integrates torrefaction, gasification, and methanol synthesis technologies and is designed to enable rapid, serial scale-up to commercial scale biomethanol production for the global market.

“Biomethanol is a key building block in the transition to low-carbon fuels for shipping, chemicals and industry,” said Rene Buwalda, CEO at Perpetual Next. “Given the availability of feedstock and the related infrastructure which is very strong, we see a strong opportunity to accelerate responsible bio-methanol deployment in the southeastern United States through the roll-out of our Biomethanol Blueprint. It enables us to advance biomethanol as a practical, scalable solution for the energy and material transition.”

title: Minister O'Brien SAF visit - News & Events - Trinity College Dublin
description:
Posted on: 21 January 2026 Minister for Transport Darragh O'Brien visited the Trinity College Dublin Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) Research Facility at SMBC Aviation Capital's headquarters in Dublin earlier this week.
As the sector works toward net-zero emissions by 2050, Sustainable Aviation Fuel is emerging as the most viable near-term decarbonisation solution available.
The visit comes following the recent publication of Ireland's Sustainable Aviation Fuel Policy Roadmap by the Department of Transport, which was assisted by the Sustainable Aviation Fuel Task Force, including aviation lessors and other key stakeholders.
“I am delighted to have the opportunity to see first-hand the Trinity College Dublin SAF Research Facility.
Professor Stephen Dooley, Director of the Trinity College SAF Research Facility, said: “Sustainable Aviation Fuels are the essential method to decarbonise aviation.
text:
Posted on: 21 January 2026

Minister for Transport Darragh O'Brien visited the Trinity College Dublin Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) Research Facility at SMBC Aviation Capital's headquarters in Dublin earlier this week. The visit underscores Ireland's commitment to advancing sustainable aviation and accelerating the decarbonisation of the global aviation sector.

The research facility, located at SMBC Aviation Capital's Fitzwilliam 28 offices, represents a unique collaboration between the aircraft leasing industry and academia to address one of aviation's most pressing challenges. As the sector works toward net-zero emissions by 2050, Sustainable Aviation Fuel is emerging as the most viable near-term decarbonisation solution available.

SAF is a "drop-in" alternative to conventional jet fuel that can be used in existing aircraft and engines, resulting in lifecycle CO₂ emissions reductions of up to 70-80%. While challenges around affordability and availability remain, SAF represents the current best option for reducing aviation's carbon footprint in the short to medium term.

The visit comes following the recent publication of Ireland's Sustainable Aviation Fuel Policy Roadmap by the Department of Transport, which was assisted by the Sustainable Aviation Fuel Task Force, including aviation lessors and other key stakeholders. The Roadmap identifies key opportunities and pathways for advancing SAF deployment in Ireland.

The Trinity College Dublin SAF Research Facility supports the EU SAF Clearing House, sponsored by the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA), providing pre-screening and advisory services to early-stage fuel producers. This work bridges critical scientific, regulatory, and commercial gaps that currently inhibit SAF scale-up. The facility, is also supported by Aircraft Leasing Ireland, Ryanair and Research Ireland.

Professor Stephen Dooley explains the work of the team at the Trinity College Dublin SAF Research Facility at SMBC Aviation Capital Headquarters,

Minister for Transport, Darragh O’Brien, said: “This marks an important opportunity to acknowledge the ongoing collaboration between SMBC Aviation Capital and Trinity College Dublin, with wider support from Aircraft Leasing Ireland, Ryanair and Research Ireland, to progress the development of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF).

“This collaborative approach exemplifies the commitment of the sector to decarbonising aviation, and acknowledges the crucial role that SAF will play in achieving this. I would also like to take this opportunity to acknowledge the significant level of engagement my Department received from all stakeholders in the development of Ireland’s first Sustainable Aviation Fuel Policy Roadmap, which I published last summer.

“I am delighted to have the opportunity to see first-hand the Trinity College Dublin SAF Research Facility. With implementation of our Sustainable Aviation Fuel Policy Roadmap, the expertise of our academia, lessors, airlines and other key stakeholders, I am confident Ireland will continue to be at the forefront of delivering innovation for the sector.”

Peter Barrett, CEO, SMBC Aviation Capital, said: “It was a privilege to welcome Minister for Transport, Darragh O’Brien to the Trinity College Dublin SAF Research facility located at our Dublin headquarters. The development and adoption of sustainable aviation fuel is a critical decarbonisation lever for the industry, and meaningful progress depends on strong collaboration between policymakers, academia and the private sector. We are proud to contribute to this effort and this visit reflects the shared commitment to building a more sustainable aviation future.”

Minister Darragh O'Brien, Professor Stephen Dooley and collaborators from Trinity and SMBC Aviation Capital meet at the facility in SMBC Capital Aviation Headquarters.

Professor Stephen Dooley, Director of the Trinity College SAF Research Facility, said: “Sustainable Aviation Fuels are the essential method to decarbonise aviation. SAFs are being made from a wide range of non-fossil feedstocks by technological innovations from all over the world. Due to the safety requirements of aviation, all aviation fuels including SAFs are subject to rigorous data intensive technical evaluation.

"Currently this evaluation is performed on a case by case basis, and this is the work that the SAF Research Facility as partner to the EU SAF Clearing House managed by EASA, performs to advance SAF Producer’s commercial readiness with data that shows they have a viable product, and with coaching to show how the product can be made viable.”

title: Study: Iowa corn and ethanol industry will 'continue downward trend' without new market access
description:
The study follows what the U.S. Department of Agriculture called a record year of corn production, with Iowa farmers growing 2.77 billion bushels of corn in 2025.
In a call with reporters Wednesday, Iowa corn and ethanol leaders, referencing the study conducted by Decision Innovation Solutions, said the demand gap – or the distance between total corn use and total corn production – will continue to increase.
The Decision Innovation Solutions study was “prepared for” Iowa Corn Growers Association and the Iowa Renewable Fuel Association, according to the report.
According to the study, the ultra-low carbon ethanol markets are large enough to sustain continued growth in corn production.
“Not all these fuel requirements will be filled with ultra-low carbon ethanol,” the study said.
text:
A recent study prepared for the Iowa corn and ethanol industries predicts that without expanded markets, the “best days for corn growers are in the past.”

The study, and industry advocates, said the passage of year-round E15, a 15% ethanol ratio blend of fuel, will provide relief to farmers in the short term, but access to ultra-low carbon ethanol fuels will be necessary to sustain corn growers past 2030.

The study follows what the U.S. Department of Agriculture called a record year of corn production, with Iowa farmers growing 2.77 billion bushels of corn in 2025.

In a call with reporters Wednesday, Iowa corn and ethanol leaders, referencing the study conducted by Decision Innovation Solutions, said the demand gap – or the distance between total corn use and total corn production – will continue to increase. A bigger demand gap means lower corn prices, assuming 2025 corn acreage figures persist, which would make it harder for farmers to stay in business.

The Decision Innovation Solutions study was “prepared for” Iowa Corn Growers Association and the Iowa Renewable Fuel Association, according to the report.

Mark Mueller, Iowa Corn Growers Association president and a farmer near Waverly, said farmers are already working on “very very tight margins.”

“I am a fourth-generation farmer, and I am nervous that there won’t be a fifth generation Mueller farming on my family land,” Mueller said. “…The bottom line is that we have high input prices, we have low commodity prices, and we’re producing more corn all the time. We need more places to move our corn, and while Iowa corn is working towards that, it’s just a tough, tough road for the farming community.”

The study examined several potential trajectories for corn and ethanol industries. First, if production trends continue to increase, corn acreage planted remains at 2025 levels and ethanol demand is not increased by the nationwide, year-round sale of E15 fuel, the demand gap “rises sharply.”

Monte Shaw, the executive director of the Iowa Renewable Fuels Association, said this option puts the farm economy into a “capital C crisis” where farmers would be asking taxpayers for tens of billions of dollars in farm support payments.

If Congress is able to pass a bill permitting the year-round sale of 15% ethanol blends at gas stations nationwide, the study shows it would increase corn demand by about 2.1 billion bushels by 2031.

According to the study, the expanded ethanol market with E15 fuels would cause the demand gap to diminish, reaching almost zero by 2030. The electrification and improved fuel efficiency of vehicles, combined with farmers’ anticipated increases in production, would cause the gap to again increase after 2031.

Shaw said he hopes nationwide, year-round E15 can be included one of the final spending bills Congress has to pass this year.

“I think that’s going to be the single most important ag-policy decision that’s made this decade,” Shaw said. “It literally sets us up to move forward or to go into a very bad place.”

Dave Miller, chief economist with Decision Innovation Solutions, said ethanol production will have to turn to marine and aviation markets as the industries begin to transition away from fossil fuels.

“E15 is not a sufficient long-term solution,” Miller said. “It is a near-term solution that is very powerful, but in the long run, we need to be able to take, and access, two great big markets that exist.”

Ethanol and corn industry leaders say the best way for them to enter the ultra-low carbon ethanol market, which is the type of fuel the marine and aviation industries seek, is to obtain access to carbon capture and sequestration technologies.

Several companies have attempted to build carbon sequestration pipelines through Iowa to connect to ethanol plants for this purpose over the past several years. The Summit Carbon Solutions pipeline obtained a permit from the state regulating board, but the progress of the pipeline has been tied up in legal and legislative fights.

Environmental groups like the Sierra Club Iowa Chapter and groups of landowners argue the transportation of sequestered carbon dioxide is not a public use, and therefore that the pipeline should not be able to use eminent domain to obtain rights-of-way.

The House is scheduled to debate a bill Wednesday that would ban the use of eminent domain for carbon capture pipelines, and Summit says, would kill the project. A bill in the Senate seeks to address the issue by allowing pipeline operators to deviate from their approved paths in favor of landowners who are willing to have the pipeline on their properties.

Shaw said this is the second battle the ethanol and corn industries have to fight.

“Right now there are people who are trying to slam the door on the future markets of Iowa agriculture, and we’re trying hard to say, no, let’s not do that,” Shaw said.

According to the study, the ultra-low carbon ethanol markets are large enough to sustain continued growth in corn production. Per the study, the marine fuel market represents a 70-80 billion gallon per-year fuel market and sustainable aviation fuel has the potential for 35 billion gallons per year.

“Not all these fuel requirements will be filled with ultra-low carbon ethanol,” the study said. “But these new markets are sufficiently large to close the gap on corn demand through 2050, if only we have the foresight to do so.”
